statement:
**Theorem.** The ring of integers of an algebraic number field contains
infinitely many prime ideals.\
*Proof.* Let $\mathcal{O}$ be the ring of integers of a number field. If
$p$ is a rational prime number, then the principal ideal $(p)$ of
$\mathcal{O}$ does not coincide with $(1) = \mathcal{O}$ and thus $(p)$
has a set of prime ideals of $\mathcal{O}$ as factors. Two different
(positive) rational primes $p$ and $q$ satisfy
$$\gcd((p),\,(q)) \;=\; (p,\,q) \;=\; (1),$$ since there exist integers
$x$ and $y$ such that $xp\!+\!yq = 1$ and consequently $1 \in (p,\,q)$.
Therefore, the principal ideals $(p)$ and $(q)$ of $\mathcal{O}$ have no
common prime ideal factors. Because there are , also the corresponding
principal ideals have infinitely many different prime ideal factors.
